list_definition.definition: the back part of the mouth connecting the openings of the stomach, lungs and nose
the front part of the neck

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She wore a silver brooch at her throat.

list_ex_of_english: He was humble minded and never forced his opinions down other people's throats.
He said that you must avoid the impression of thrusting religion down the throats of the pupils.
Surely, if we do that, we are saying we prefer to cut our throats rather than survive.
Depending on populations surveyed, the climate and the season, the germ can be recovered from 5% to 50% of the throats of schoolchildren examined.
If we do not, we shall cut each other's throats.
Instead, it has added instability and set people at each other's throats.
We did not vote for national health service trusts, but they were forced down our throats.
Politicians love grabbing each other's throats!
